body:
So I've found a bug, but I don't think it's the bug you're experiencing.
Suggest you download the dev build from:

https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/pull/6291 (build page: https://build.syncthing.net/viewLog.html?buildId=53240&buildTypeId=Syncthing_BuildLinuxCross&tab=artifacts) 

and see if it fixes it.
If not, provide the logs again, as this build adds verbose logging back in.
Which one should I download for the x86_64 architecture?
x86_64 is named amd64 in the artifacts.
Its amd64 and whatever your os is.

Thanks. I've copied the binary over the installed syncthing 1.3.2 and restarted the service.
My problem has gone, syncthing works nicely again over my socks proxy.
So it seems your fix has fixed this problem as well. Thank you!

Should I have closed this issue myself, or was my post enough for clarification? Just asking so I know about the policy here.

I don't think there is any applicable policy in this case. Essentially we want to close once we are sure the commit landed in master. In theory it should have asked you to test before merging, but the bug was so obvious that I didn't bother waiting.
Perfect, this is fine with me, thanks.

I'm sorry to say but this bug is again present in Syncthing v1.3.4.
```
Feb 19 00:13:04 FrankVM syncthing[34745]: [YSBJ4] INFO: Joined relay relay://83.240.51.14:443
Feb 19 00:17:54 FrankVM syncthing[34745]: [YSBJ4] INFO: Listen (BEP/relay): joining session: socks connect tcp localhost:8010->127.0.0.1:443: unknown error general SOCKS server failure
```
I had to downgrade to v1.3.2 again.
What is odd, in this thread I tried in https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/issues/6289#issuecomment-578033162 which was successful but now it gives the same error. Either I missed something the last time or some dependency has changed in the meantime.
Can we reopen this issue please?
The fix will only be present in 1.4.0. You can upgrade to the release candidate to work around it.
Opps, I certainly missed the  v1.4.0 milestone indeed. But the second part of my comment worries me if there is a fix at all.
Sure, in that case I have no idea, as nothing else changed in that area. The error is coming from the proxy server in your case.
It still works beautifully with Syncthing v1.3.2.
So I tried v1.4.0 and it gives the same error. Hence this issue is not solved yet. Could we please reopen it?

Can you run 1.4.0-rc.7 with `STTRACE=dialer`, or by enabling dialer tracing in the logging screen in the GUI, and collect some output to see what's going on?

No need to upgrade your primary setup, just start a new instance with `syncthing -home /tmp/whatever`

It's a generic proxy error tho, not something coming from our code, so I am not sure what we can do here. We potentially picked up a newer version of the proxy libraries moving to a new version of go?

It looks like it's trying to do a proxy connect to localhost, which will clearly get rejected by the proxy.

```
socks connect tcp localhost:8010->127.0.0.1:443:
```

I have no idea why it would want to do that. It's an odd coincidence that it would start when we refactor dialling and stuff. I'd like to see some more tracing.

Thanks guys for dealing with this problem!
Here is the log as requested: 
https://gist.githubusercontent.com/SanskritFritz/cb6d14b1b6ec749b736a2c920e627bc9/raw/5a80a3ef721174cf1036791b15356399e99eaab4/gistfile1.txt
This is how I ran the test:
```
#!/bin/bash
export all_proxy='socks5://localhost:8010' 
export ALL_PROXY_NO_FALLBACK=1 
export http_proxy= 
export https_proxy= 
export GOMAXPROCS=1
export STTRACE=dialer
./syncthing -home /home/frank/temp/syncthing_temp/
```

Everything looks fine from the logs for far, but it doesn't get to the point where your logs are showing the problem because you terminated it.

Your proxy is blocking any connections that are not going to port 80 or 443, most relays listen on port 22067 which your proxy is refusing.
It does eventually pick a relay that happens to be listening on 443.

But I think I see the problem.
Oh sorry. Should I leave it running longer?
